node.text:
Take Pokemon-like gameplay, throw in NFTs and you have Axie Infinity.

The game lets players like 22-year-old John Aaron Ramos accumulate tradeable crypto coins and earn real money — in his case, enough to buy two apartments. (via @quicktake)

node.title: Axie Infinity: How a Game is Turning Players Into Crypto Traders

node.text: NFTs burst on the scene with a $69 million sale of Beeple's digital art. Now players behind the so-called metaverse are betting "digital scarcity" will create a whole new ecosystem of play and commerce.

node.title: How NFTs Are Reinventing the Digital World

node.text:
"I would describe cryptocurrencies as a limited supply of nothing."

John Paulson—who's famous bet against subprime housing made him and investors $20 billion—says crypto is a "worthless" bubble and he calls SPACs, one of the hottest investing tools, a losing proposition.

Paulson told @bloombergtv in an interview on "Bloomberg Wealth with David Rubenstein" he's more concerned about rising prices. The rapidly expanding money supply could push inflation rates well above current expectations, he said, and gold, which he’s backed for years, is primed for its moment.

Paulson’s dismissal of crypto is sure to attract critics after digital assets vastly outperformed gold in recent years. Watch the full episode Tuesday at 9pm ET on BloombergTV and read the Big Take in our stories.

node.title: Cryptocurrencies are a Bubble, Says Billionaire Paulson

node.text: Frackers in America’s largest oil field are letting massive amounts of methane spill into the atmosphere. These scientists and activists are trying to find the leaks and get them plugged before they cook the planet further.

node.title: The Methane Hunters Racing to Change the Course of Global Warming

node.title: What Happens When You Mix Covid Vaccines?

node.text: Few people have lost as much money as quickly as Bill Hwang. In March, the previously unknown Wall Street whale and his family firm, Archegos, triggered losses of more than $20 billion in just two days. The result was one of the most spectacular implosions in modern financial history. (via @businessweek)

node.title: How Archegos Capital Cost Wall Street $20 Billion

node.text:
China's growing ranks of rural entrepreneurs are getting rich peddling their produce on social media. 

One of the scene's stars is Jin Guowei, aka Brother Pomegranate — an internet sensation with 7.3 million followers and 300 million yuan ($46 million) of sales in 2020. (video via @quicktake)

node.title: Livestreaming Farmers Earn Millions From Fruit on China’s TikTok

node.text:
In almost every way measurable, millennials in the U.S. at 40 are doing worse financially than the generations that came before them.

Fewer millennials own homes than their parents did at their age. They have more debt — especially student debt. They simply aren’t as wealthy. 

Now, if predictions of a long, post-Covid economic boom are to be believed, this may be the last opportunity an entire generation has to build wealth before heading off into retirement.

node.title: Millennials Are Running Out of Time to Build Wealth to Retire

node.text: When employees at software company 10Pines want a raise, they pitch their co-workers, not their boss. Here's what happens when a firm uses "radical transparency" to attract and retain talent.

node.title: Would You Let Your Colleagues Decide Your Salary?

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on September 10, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Ajudge deals a huge blow to the App Store in Epic antitrust case Bloomberg'.

node.text:
In one of the most highly anticipated rulings facing big tech, Apple’s been told by a judge to change how it operates its lucrative App Store. 

Apple was ordered to allow developers to steer consumers to outside payment methods for mobile apps, in a ruling that is a severe blow to the iPhone maker. 

A federal judge granted an injunction sought by Epic Games Friday while also ordering the game maker to pay damages to Apple for breach of contract. The order could take a big bite out of the profitability of the App Store. According to analysts the App Store takes in more than $20 billion a year with a profit margin above 75%.

The decision is a significant setback for the world’s most valuable company as it faces growing antitrust scrutiny from lawmakers and global regulators. 

Apple is expected to appeal, setting the stage for the fight to carry on for at least another year and possibly make its way to the U.S. Supreme Court. Read more in our link in bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on September 10, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'Renate Nyborg is appointed Tinder's first female CEO Bloomberg'.

node.text:
Match has named Renate Nyborg as the new CEO of its leading brand, Tinder.

Nyborg most recently served as Tinder’s general manager of Europe, Middle East and Africa. She joined the company in October from mental-health startup Headspace, and previously spent four years at Apple.

The first female CEO since Tinder’s inception also has first-hand experience on the dating app — she met her husband on it. Tap the link in our bio for more on her rise.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on September 10, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, outdoors, tree and text that says '00000 Generation 9/11: Following the parents they lost onto Wall Street Bloomberg'.

node.text:
Some 3,000 children lost a parent in the terror attacks on 9/11. Two decades later, they are grown up and chasing their own dreams. A few dozen have sworn an oath, like their parents once did, to serve New York as firefighters or police officers. Others have followed the ones they lost onto Wall Street — some into the very same investment firms.

The 20th commemoration feels particularly poignant for Wall Street's 9/11 generation. They're making their way and looking forward — and, at the same time, always looking back. Some wanted to follow in their parent's last footsteps. Others simply discovered they liked finance and had a head for numbers. Or maybe, as in the case of Maggie Smith, who started at Piper Sandler in July, it was a bit of both.

"It's really special, and it makes me very, very happy that I have the opportunity to grow the memory of him and create my own legacy at the same time," Smith says of her father, Jeffrey, who was just 36 and had been at Sandler O'Neill for five years. "I want to be able to have an impact on the company in the way that my dad wasn’t able to." Read more at the link in bio.

Photo by Bloomberg Business on September 10, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'WFH has left some younger employees struggling with "office chat" Bloomberg'.

node.text:
Feeling like pandemic working has made you less fluent in office talk? You’re not alone.

More than half of young employees in the U.K. say working from home has taken a toll on their office conversation skills, according to a LinkedIn survey. Some see it as potentially harming their career progression and pay.

Executives also polled by the social network have one possible solution: a majority plan to boost budgets for social events to help young staff compensate for lost time. Link in bio for more.

buttons.text: Visit the COVID-19 Information Center for vaccine resources.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on September 09, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'Biden orders shots for millions, calling unvaccinated a threat Bloomber'.

node.text:
President Joe Biden said he’d order all executive branch employees, federal contractors and millions of health-care workers to be vaccinated against the coronavirus, and that his administration would issue rules requiring large private employers to mandate shots or testing.

“My message to unvaccinated Americans is this: What more is there to wait for? What more do you need to see?” he said. “We’ve been patient, but our patience is wearing thin. And your refusal has cost all of us, so please, do the right thing.”

The new measures are Biden’s response to Covid’s resurgence driven by the delta variant and the tens of millions of Americans who have refused vaccinations. Federal employees who don’t comply could be dismissed and private employers might be fined.  Read more at the link in bio.

buttons.text: Visit the COVID-19 Information Center for vaccine resources.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on September 09, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, standing and text that says 'NO JAB NO JOB NO WAY! These are the U.S. companies requiring vaccines for their employees Bloomberg'.

node.text:
To mandate, or not to mandate? That is the question facing U.S. companies right now as they weigh the pros and cons of requiring a Covid-19 vaccine for employees. The answers, so far, are all over the place.

A Bloomberg compilation of policies at more than 100 big companies found that about half have implemented a vaccine mandate for at least some of their U.S. staff, but the requirements vary widely. Several are also offering incentives to persuade reluctant staff, from gift cards to a few hours’ pay, to a lottery with payouts of up to $500,000. See who’s doing what at the link in bio.

📷: Spencer Platt/Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on September 09, 2021. May be an image of 2 people, people standing and text that says 'solar startup borninagarage garage is beating China SUnAVE cheaper a panels NDRIVE INDIVE Bloomberg'.

node.text:
An Australian startup has produced one of the most efficient solar cells of all time — beating China’s industrial giants in the process.

Vince Allen and David Hu co-founded SunDrive Solar seven years ago. Allen had built an R&D suite in his garage, and after hundreds of experiments, he got his breakthrough: successfully replacing expensive silver in solar panels with copper.

Labs and well-funded giants have struggled with the same approach, and startups in this part of the solar market are rare because of the daunting prospect of competing against the huge Chinese companies that produce solar cells by the millions. Tap the link in our bio for more on their discovery.

May be an image of 1 person, standing and text that says '심야 열병식 개최 합참' 면밀 추적중" YT 코로나19 국내발생 2,01 해외유입 례 심야열병 기공개 용석·김세의구속영장 김세의 구속영장 원-100엔 1061.97 |원-100엔1061.97 97 5.3 Trim, tanned Kim Trim,tannedKimJongUn Un takes center stagea military parade Bloomberg'.

node.text:
Kim Jong Un looks very much like he's had a makeover.

The North Korean leader took the spotlight at a military parade on Thursday — with a thinner frame, a trace of a tan and a haircut reminiscent of his grandfather, Kim Il Sung.
 
There were no major new weapons on display at the event, helping focus attention on a new-look Kim after years of speculation about his health. Tap the link in our bio for more.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business in Goldman Sachs. May be an image of 1 person, standing and text that says '生式 행보문지 Goldman Sachs ends social distancing andfreefoodinits London office Bloomberg'.

node.text:
Goldman Sachs will drop social distancing rules and end free meals at its office in London, the bank's latest steps toward a return to pre-pandemic normality.

About half of London staff are already back at the office, according to an internal memo. Bosses plan to return to full occupancy starting next week, and the offer of free food will end on Sept. 20 "to encourage support of the local restaurants and businesses reopening around us."

Tap the link in our bio for more.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on September 08, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'GameStop Stop plunges after new CEO disappoints Reddit investors 22-6210248.43 GameStop® ® Bloomberg'.

node.text:
GameStop's legions of meme-stock fans were primed to hear a new CEO confidently point the path forward. Instead, the struggling video-game retailer posted a wider-than-expected loss in the second quarter, took no questions on a call with analysts and lost 11% of its market value in late trading.

After a more than 10-fold runup in the stock this year, the Reddit crowd’s belief in GameStop’s potential is running into the reality that a turnaround will take time and patience.

While GameStop started bleeding long before the pandemic, but lockdowns haven't helped. Find out more at the link in bio.

:camera:: Rafael Henrique/SOPA Images/LightRocket via Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on September 08, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, screen and text that says 'Does buying the dip actually work for Bitcoin dmeme stock traders? Bloomberg Wealth'.

node.text:
When Bitcoin plunged on Tuesday, El Salvador’s President Nayib Bukele tweeted a version of the three words that have become a mantra for meme stock traders: Buy the dip.

This past year, those three words have ricocheted across social media as a rallying cry any time a meme asset slumps. AMC shares in freefall? “Buy the dip,” Redditors cry. Crypto taking a slide? Cue a flock of “buy the dip” tweets. A celebrity SPAC is spiraling downward? Telegram groups alight with prods from hopeful buyers.

In light of all the hype, gains and losses this year, two professors wanted to know if the strategy helps or harms investors. Read more about what they found at the link in bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on September 08, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, standing and text that says 'Companies could lose millions over Texas abortionlaw DONTMESS ONT READ ME ARMS TIRED Bloomberg'.

node.text:
Portland’s plan to boycott Texas goods and services over its new abortion law could cost Texas companies millions of dollars a year, according to city officials.

Heather Hafer, a spokeswoman with the Office of Management and Finance, said Portland has inked almost $35 million in contracts with Texas-based businesses over the last five years, The Oregonian reported. The Portland City Council is scheduled to vote Wednesday on the measure, which would halt the city from spending money with Texas businesses as well as forbid employee travel to the state. Find out more at the link in bio.

📷: Sergio Flores/Getty Images
